Cats hand Longhorns first loss

Victory is closest for the Cats this season.

Cats hand Longhorns first loss

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 12:03 a.m. EST December 6, 2014
Buy Photo

UK's Willie Cauley-Stein shoots the ball during the University of Kentucky men's basketball game against Texas at Rupp Arena in Lexington, Ky. Friday, December 5, 2014.(Photo: Mike Weaver/Special to The Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

18 CONNECT 10 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. If you want to test the top-ranked University of Kentucky basketball team, bring some big guys and come ready to fight. Sixth-ranked Texas, one of the few teams in America that can come close to the Wildcats' size, followed that formula to a moral victory Friday night at Rupp Arena.

Thanks to junior 7-footer Willie Cauley-Stein, though, it was an actual loss, 63-51, for the Longhorns.

That was the narrowest margin yet for Kentucky (8-0), which won its first seven games by an average of 34.4 points. Playing without its starting point guard and leading scorer, Texas (7-1) led early, was tied at halftime and trailed by just five with 1:44 remaining in the game.

With no fear and five players at least 6-8 and 240 pounds, the Horns dominated the Cats on the glass in the first half 27 rebounds to 11 and allowed just eight points in the paint before the break. Kentucky, with seven guys at least 6-8 and four who are 6-10 or taller, came in averaging 15.6 more rebounds per game than its opponents.

"The beginning of that game was vicious arms flying, bodies flying," Cats coach John Calipari said. "It was a dogfight, and their dogs were bigger in the first half."

Except for Cauley-Stein, who was unfazed by Texas' height or fight, and delivered arguably the best performance of his college career, which he punctuated with a soaring slam off a lob to polish off the pesky Horns in the final minute.

In front of 38 NBA executives and scouts, and with basketball power broker William Wesley cheering wildly for the Wildcats courtside, Cauley-Stein went off for 21 points, 12 rebounds, five steals and three blocks. He helped hold Texas to 29.8 percent shooting from the field and drew the fifth fouls of both its former McDonald's All-Americans: 6-9, 285-pound Cameron Ridley and 6-11 Myles Turner.

This from a guy who used to shy away from contact in the paint.

"Now he's finally embracing it," junior forward Alex Poythress said. "He wants to get fouled. He wants to go in and get and-ones. He actually during the game said, 'Let me go down low.' "

Cauley-Stein played 33 minutes, as UK's slow start and a slugfest of a game 51 combined fouls and 61 free throws led Calipari to abandon his two-platoon system early. The Cats still found a way to finish strong.

Leading just 51-46 with four and a half minutes left, Cauley-Stein snared an offensive rebound and scored, then reached into a passing lane for a steal, which led to point guard Andrew Harrison burying a 3-pointer in the corner with 3:17 to go.

That extended Kentucky's streak to 908 consecutive games with a made three. The Cats missed their first 11. The difference, however, was on the glass, where UK battled to a 20-15 advantage in the second half.

That helped the Wildcats blitz the Horns out of halftime with 10 unanswered points and an 18-2 run over the first nine minutes. But the visitors didn't wilt, using an 11-2 burst of their own to close within five points with 4:37 remaining.

That's when Cauley-Stein swooped in for a put-back and a bit of breathing room, validating Calipari's halftime message to fellow big man Marcus Lee. Unless Cauley-Stein gets tired, he told Lee, you're not playing this game.

"Willie said, 'Just be ready for me, but I'm going to try to go blow this out,' " Calipari said, "and that's what he did."

Only after an ugly first half. Each team attempted 25 shots, with the Cats making only eight and the Longhorns sinking just seven. Texas turned it over 13 times to offset its rebounding advantage and the two sides slogged to a 26-all tie at the break.

Kentucky had four guys with multiple fouls, including 6-10 Trey Lyles and 7-footer Dakari Johnson with three apiece by the 2:36 mark of the first half. The Wildcats also went nearly six minutes without a made field goal, missing eight straight shots, and fell behind 20-14 with 5:19 to go before the break.

But when Jonathan Holmes hammered Karl-Anthony Towns on his way to a dunk, resulting in a Flagrant 1 foul, it ignited the Rupp Arena crowd and the Cats.

Towns got up from a nasty spill and sank two free throws, then swished a corner jump shot off the ensuing inbounds play. He snared a rebound on the other end and point guard Tyler Ulis buried a shot from the top of the key. The Cats scored six straight points in 20 seconds and the crowd roared.

Cauley-Stein sank a hook shot to make it an 8-0 run in only a minute to give UK the lead. He was the Wildcats' one post player up to the challenge in the first half. The rest of the team finally matched his effort in the second.

"I don't know if I have ever coached a game where the size and the strength and physicality was what it was," Texas coach Rick Barnes said. "I'm sure if you asked the referees, too, I don't think they have ever officiated a game like that. That was a big-boy game."

Kentucky turned out to be just a little bit bigger.

Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
